bug.author: barak
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h4>Issue description</denchmark-h>
The Debian ensmallen package is automatically built (compiled) on many architectures. The build process runs the test scripts. Everything works fine on some architectures (amd64, say) albeit with a rather large amount of time required for the test phase. But on some other architectures (i386, see <denchmark-link:https://buildd.debian.org/status/fetch.php?pkg=ensmallen&arch=i386&ver=2.10.0-1&stamp=1568047415>https://buildd.debian.org/status/fetch.php?pkg=ensmallen&arch=i386&ver=2.10.0-1&stamp=1568047415</denchmark-link> for details) the test phase exceeds some resource limitation and the build is terminated. I could just turn off testing, but that seems wrong. Best would be if the test phase were much faster, or if there was a fast test run by default with the current extremely time consuming test run only if some extra option is given. <denchmark-h:h4>Your environment</denchmark-h>
version of ensmallen: 2.10.0 operating system: Debian/unstable compiler: GCC 9.x
<denchmark-h:h4>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
Clone <denchmark-link:https://github.com/barak/ensmallen>https://github.com/barak/ensmallen</denchmark-link> , go to tag debian/2.10.0-1, run on a crappy machine with a low ulimit set. <denchmark-h:h4>Expected behavior</denchmark-h>
ensmallen sucessfully autobuilt on all sorts of weird architectures. <denchmark-h:h4>Actual behavior</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-link:https://buildd.debian.org/status/package.php?p=ensmallen>https://buildd.debian.org/status/package.php?p=ensmallen</denchmark-link>
